description: This graduate course provides an overview of current issues in English language education with a particular focus on issues in culture, the development of World Englishes and the roles of Non-native English speaking teachers (NNEST) in ELT.  The course will encourage students to reflect critically about the relations between language, power, social and cultural practices, and to explore topics of their own interest.
goals: Gain knowledge about some of the main issues in culture and politics discussed in the field of English language education.
Understand theories, perspectives, and arguments related to the above issues.
Explore how the theories, perspectives, and arguments can be incorporated in a potential research study of one’s own interest.
Develop deeper awareness of the roles of Non-native English speaking professional in the ELT field.
syllabus:
### COURSE DESCRIPTION:

This course examines the different theories and practices in teaching ELLs at beginning, intermediate and advanced levels within the framework of culture and ELT.  Approaches to literacy instruction will be explored, using theories, research, and current methods for bilingual and biliteracy development.  We will also examine the role of cultural practices in the development of biliteracy and multiliteracy. Participants will evaluate their practices in light of the course content, generate new approaches, and draft appropriate outcomes for literacy instruction for ELLs. 

**COURSE OBJECTIVES:**

1.   Through course readings and class discussions, expand the understanding and awareness of biliteracy and multiliteracy development and practices, language and cultural issues critical to the effective methodology and instructional practices for students learning in two or more languages.

2.   Review L1 (Native Language Art) and L2 (English Language Art) or L3 acquisition process.

3.   Become familiar with current research and theories about L1 (NLA) and L2 (English) language acquisition, reading acquisition and the stages of development.

4.   Students will develop a plan for implementing process-oriented biliteracy and multileracy activities, bilingual materials and appropriate methods of assessment and evaluation for the case study. 

5.  Students will understand the socio-cultural nature of language and its implication for the classroom within the framework of world Englishes.

 COURSE REQUIREMENTS  

**1****.  Demonstration of thoughtful completion of readings:**

Participants are expected to complete the reading assignments prior to the class and should be prepared to discuss them in class (announced one week prior to the meeting). With partners, present and lead a discussion in class on one of the topics.  

**2\.  Field visits (conference day) and reflective responses:**

Participants will go to two international conferences (weeks 3 & 8) in applied linguistics & TESOL and write a reflective response for each visit.

**3.  Research Project/ Case Study:**

The final project will be a **case study of an ELL (or more)** and will focus on a literacy-related area of interest for the participant. 

Topics may include, but are not limited to:

\-EFL literacy in the native/primary language or FL from a sociocultural framework

\-Taiwan's EFL education policy in regard to the framework of world Englishes

\-biliteracy or multiliteracy in elementary grades or high school

\-native language literacy in the content areas (Taiwan's CLIL or EMI policy in higher education)

The final project will demonstrate how an ELL (or more) applies literacy strategies to his/her situation. Topics are open to what's been included in this course within culture and ELT. This case study will showcase your ability to conduct independent research at a small scale linking theory and practice to foster your critical thinking skill. 

Class schedule

The core texts will be two textbooks along with a reading packet of journal articles selected thematically (EIL, ELF, world Englishes, language & cultural identities, native & non-native English speakers, intercultural communication, language, race and power...etc).  Topics will be integrated into the following themes (subject to change based on our progress and need):

Week 1.      Introduction

Week 2.      Language variation & what is language? (Mooney et al. (2011) chapter 1)

Week 3.      Conference day

Week 4.      Language thought and representation (Mooney et al. (2011) chapter 2)

Week 5.      Language and politics (Mooney et al. (2011) chapter 3)

Week 6.      Spring break

Week 7.      Faces of bilingualism (Bialystok (2001) chapter 1)  

Week 8.      Conference day

Week 9.      Starting with one language (Bialystok (2001) chapter 2)  

Week 10.    Midterm presentation 

Week 11.    And adding another  (Bialystok (2001) chapter 3)  

Week 12.    Language in the mind (Bialystok (2001) chapter 4) 

Week 13.    Thinking about language (Bialystok (2001) chapter 5)  

Week 14.    Link to literacy (Bialystok (2001) chapter 6)  

Week 15.    Beyond language (Bialystok (2001) chapter 7)  

Week 16.    The extent of the bilingual mind (Bialystok (2001) chapter 8)  

Week 17.    Final presentation 

Week 18.    Final presentation
